procedure: Medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction, left knee
extraction_data.summary: 24-year-old female with recurrent patellar instability after multiple dislocations underwent medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction and lateral release of the left knee. The procedure involved allograft fixation to the patella and femur with bioabsorbable screws to restore patellar tracking. Postoperative plan includes immobilizer locked in extension with partial weight-bearing recommended.

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.section_title: Total Shoulder Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 9, L271)
names: Total Shoulder Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 9, L271)
Total shoulder replacement (Evidence: pg no: 7, L174)
full_source.description: Prosthetic replacement of the humeral head and the glenoid (total arthroplasty) is most commonly performed for joint damage due to osteoarthritis. Total shoulder arthroplasty requires an intact medial glenoid to support the glenoid prosthesis. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L173-L175)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Anticipated level of function should place limited demands on the shoulder joint (Evidence: pg no: 9, L267)
Deltoid muscle must be intact (Evidence: pg no: 9, L268)
Shoulder joint must be anatomically and structurally suited to receive selected implants (Evidence: pg no: 9, L269-L270)
Limited range of motion or crepitus of the glenohumeral joint on physical examination (Evidence: pg no: 9, L277)
Pain and loss of function of at least 6 months' duration that interferes with daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 9, L278)
Radiographic evidence of destructive degenerative joint disease (Evidence: pg no: 9, L279-L286)
Failure of conservative management of at least 6 weeks' duration (Evidence: pg no: 9, L287-L288)

exclusions: Total shoulder arthroplasty under conditions which would result in excessive stress on the implant including, but not limited to, Charcot joint and paralytic conditions of the shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 11, L332-L333)
Shoulder resurfacing, including total, hemi, or partial resurfacing (Evidence: pg no: 11, L334-L336)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, glenohumeral joint; total shoulder (glenoid and proximal humeral replacement (eg, total shoulder)) (Evidence: pg no: 11, L364)

full_source.notes: Indications include proximal humerus fracture not amenable to internal fixation, malignancy involving the glenohumeral joint or surrounding soft tissue, and advanced joint disease due to osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, avascular necrosis, or post-traumatic arthritis. (Evidence: pg no: 9, L272-L276)

Total shoulder arthroplasty requires an intact medial glenoid to support the glenoid prosthesis. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L173-L175)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Anticipated level of function should place limited demands on the shoulder joint (Evidence: pg no: 9, L267)
Deltoid muscle must be intact (Evidence: pg no: 9, L268)
Shoulder joint must be anatomically and structurally suited to receive selected implants (Evidence: pg no: 9, L269-L270)
Limited range of motion or crepitus of the glenohumeral joint on physical examination (Evidence: pg no: 9, L277)
Pain and loss of function of at least 6 months' duration that interferes with daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 9, L278)
Radiographic evidence of destructive degenerative joint disease (Evidence: pg no: 9, L279-L286)
Failure of conservative management of at least 6 weeks' duration (Evidence: pg no: 9, L287-L288)

exclusions: Total shoulder arthroplasty under conditions which would result in excessive stress on the implant including, but not limited to, Charcot joint and paralytic conditions of the shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 11, L332-L333)
Shoulder resurfacing, including total, hemi, or partial resurfacing (Evidence: pg no: 11, L334-L336)

full_source.notes: Indications include proximal humerus fracture not amenable to internal fixation, malignancy involving the glenohumeral joint or surrounding soft tissue, and advanced joint disease due to osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, avascular necrosis, or post-traumatic arthritis. (Evidence: pg no: 9, L272-L276)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: Prosthetic replacement of the humeral head and the glenoid (total arthroplasty) is most commonly performed for joint damage due to osteoarthritis. Total shoulder arthroplasty requires an intact medial glenoid to support the glenoid prosthesis. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L173-L175)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Anticipated level of function should place limited demands on the shoulder joint (Evidence: pg no: 9, L267)
Deltoid muscle must be intact (Evidence: pg no: 9, L268)
Shoulder joint must be anatomically and structurally suited to receive selected implants (Evidence: pg no: 9, L269-L270)
Limited range of motion or crepitus of the glenohumeral joint on physical examination (Evidence: pg no: 9, L277)
Pain and loss of function of at least 6 months' duration that interferes with daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 9, L278)
Radiographic evidence of destructive degenerative joint disease (Evidence: pg no: 9, L279-L286)
Failure of conservative management of at least 6 weeks' duration (Evidence: pg no: 9, L287-L288)

exclusions: Total shoulder arthroplasty under conditions which would result in excessive stress on the implant including, but not limited to, Charcot joint and paralytic conditions of the shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 11, L332-L333)
Shoulder resurfacing, including total, hemi, or partial resurfacing (Evidence: pg no: 11, L334-L336)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, glenohumeral joint; total shoulder (glenoid and proximal humeral replacement (eg, total shoulder)) (Evidence: pg no: 11, L364)

full_source.notes: Indications include proximal humerus fracture not amenable to internal fixation, malignancy involving the glenohumeral joint or surrounding soft tissue, and advanced joint disease due to osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, avascular necrosis, or post-traumatic arthritis. (Evidence: pg no: 9, L272-L276)

full_source.description: Diagnostic arthroscopy of the knee joint for synovial biopsy, tissue harvest, or when specific criteria are met (Evidence: pg no: 9, L393-L405)
full_source.scope: Knee arthroscopy for diagnostic purposes (Evidence: pg no: 9, L392-L405)

documentation: Presence of ONE of the following symptoms: Significant pain and functional limitation, Instability, or Limited range of motion (Evidence: pg no: 9, L395-L398)

Presence of ONE of the following physical exam findings: Limited range of motion, Joint swelling, Inconclusive specific diagnostic exam maneuvers, or Local muscle weakness or atrophy (Evidence: pg no: 9, L399-L403)
Inconclusive x-ray and/or advanced imaging studies (Evidence: pg no: 9, L404)
Failure of at least 6 weeks of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 9, L405)

exclusions: In-office diagnostic arthroscopy (e.g., mi-eye 2®) (Evidence: pg no: 9, L407)

codes.description: Arthroscopy, knee, diagnostic, with or without synovial biopsy (separate procedure) (Evidence: pg no: 16, L699)

original_chart:
OPERATIVE REPORT

Patient Name: Hannah Collins
MRN: 674512309
Date of Service: September 12, 2025
Surgeon: Dr. Miguel Torres, MD

PROCEDURES PERFORMED:
1. Medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction, left knee
2. Lateral release, left knee

INDICATIONS:
24-year-old female with recurrent patellar instability after multiple dislocations.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Chronic patellar instability, left knee

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same as above.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
Following induction of general anesthesia, the left knee was prepped and draped. Diagnostic arthroscopy confirmed lateral patellar tracking with synovitis. Small medial incision created for graft tunnels. An allograft was introduced and fixed to the patella and femur restoring patellar tracking. Lateral release performed arthroscopically to reduce lateral pressure. Wounds closed in layered fashion.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 125 mL.
COMPLICATIONS: None.
DRAINS: None.

IMPLANTS:
Bioabsorbable screws used for graft fixation. Specific sizes not recorded.

POSTOPERATIVE PLAN:
Immobilizer locked in extension. Partial weight-bearing recommended. Follow-up arranged at two weeks.

user_input_required.field: Number and dates of previous dislocations
user_input_required.reason: Documentation of multiple dislocations with specific count is required to establish medical necessity for MPFL reconstruction
user_input_required.suggestion: Document exact number of patellar dislocations and approximate dates of occurrence

user_input_required.reason: Chronicity of condition is a key factor in establishing medical necessity for surgical intervention
user_input_required.suggestion: Document how long the patient has been experiencing patellar instability symptoms (months/years)

user_input_required.reason: Failed conservative management is a critical requirement for surgical approval
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific conservative treatments attempted (physical therapy, bracing, activity modification, medications), duration of each treatment, and clinical outcomes/failure

user_input_required.reason: Impact on activities of daily living helps establish medical necessity
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific functional limitations caused by patellar instability, including impact on activities of daily living, work, sports participation, and quality of life

user_input_required.reason: Objective clinical findings are required to support surgical intervention
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific physical examination findings including patellar tracking assessment, apprehension test results, Q-angle measurement, and range of motion limitations

user_input_required.reason: Objective imaging evidence is required to support surgical intervention
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific findings from MRI and/or CT scans showing patellar tracking abnormalities, trochlear dysplasia, or other anatomical factors contributing to instability

user_input_required.reason: Complete documentation of intra-articular pathology is required for procedure justification
user_input_required.suggestion: Document condition of articular cartilage, menisci, and other intra-articular structures observed during diagnostic arthroscopy

user_input_required.reason: Specific graft information is required for complete procedural documentation
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific type of allograft used (e.g., semitendinosus, gracilis, etc.)

user_input_required.reason: Detailed surgical technique documentation is required for procedure coding and medical necessity
user_input_required.suggestion: Document tunnel positioning, tensioning method, and confirmation of proper patellar tracking after fixation

user_input_required.reason: Complete documentation of lateral release procedure is required for coding and medical necessity
user_input_required.suggestion: Document extent of lateral release, structures released, and confirmation of improved patellar tracking post-release

user_input_required.reason: Complete implant documentation is required for device tracking and billing
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific sizes, manufacturer, and lot numbers of bioabsorbable screws used

user_input_required.reason: Detailed postoperative care plan is required for comprehensive documentation
user_input_required.suggestion: Document timeline for range of motion progression, weight-bearing progression, and return to activities

recommendations.recommendation: Document specific conservative treatments attempted prior to surgery, including physical therapy duration and outcomes
Document specific number of patellar dislocations with approximate dates
Document specific imaging findings from MRI/CT that support the need for MPFL reconstruction
Document specific functional limitations caused by patellar instability
Document specific graft type, fixation technique, and confirmation of improved patellar tracking
Document complete implant specifications including sizes, manufacturer, and lot numbers

compliance_impact.before: The original operative report lacked critical elements required by multiple payers for medical necessity determination, including history of conservative management, duration of symptoms, specific number of dislocations, imaging findings, detailed physical examination, and comprehensive procedural details. The documentation was insufficient to support medical necessity for both MPFL reconstruction and lateral release procedures.
compliance_impact.after: With the recommended improvements and physician input, the operative report will contain comprehensive documentation of medical necessity including failed conservative management history, specific number and dates of dislocations, imaging findings supporting surgical intervention, detailed physical examination findings, comprehensive procedural details, and functional limitations. These improvements will address the key documentation gaps identified by all payers.
key_changes: Added structured section for conservative management history
Added placeholders for specific number and dates of patellar dislocations
Added section for preoperative imaging findings
Enhanced procedure details with specific technical elements
Added section for physical examination findings
Added comprehensive medical necessity documentation section
Improved organization with clear section headers and logical flow
